results.title: Stargate for Game Boy
results.creator_credit: Acclaim Entertainment Ltd and Beam Software
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Ra, the vicious alien ruler of Abydos, is using Stargates find resource-rich worlds to conquer and enslave its inhabitants. Only the player can stop Ra by cracking the Stargates’ codes and closing them before they can be misused. Stargate, while based on the action sci-fi franchise, is a matching puzzle game, similar to Tetris but with a 3D aspect. Tiles are dropped into a Stargate and matching three tiles with the same symbol clears the tiles. The game is lost when too many tiles fill up the space.

Adding complexity is the “address”, a set of seven symbols across the top of the screen that the player must clear by stacking three tiles of that symbol. The game features two modes. Skill Mode has the player clearing addresses before the tiles fill up. The game’s speed increases as more and more addresses are cleared. In Battle Mode, a player can play against the computer or another player via a link cable to another handheld. Clearing stacks adds them to your opponent’s field, hopefully overwhelming them and winning the match.

results.title: Warlords for Amiga
results.material_description: Floppy disk videogame. Two 3 1/2 inch floppy disks, colour map, product registration card, subscription card, Amiga Supplement sheet and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Warlords is set in the midst of the battle to control the Kingdom of Illuria. The player is put in control one of eight budding empires: The Sirians, Storm Giants, Grey Dwarves, Orcs of Kor, Elvallie, Horse Lords, Selentines, or Lord Bane. Each group has their strengths and weaknesses. The other clans are either controlled by the computer or by another player via hot seat play. The game proceeds on a turn-by-turn basis, with each player issuing commands such as to move units, attack the opposition, order cities to accrue gold, build more units or instruct their heroes to explore Illuria and complete quests before passing the turn to the next player. The game is won once a player has conquered at least half of the kingdom’s eighty cities.

results.title: The Lion King: Simba's Mighty Adventure for Game Boy Color
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, plastic cartridge case, registration card, consumer information booklet and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Simba’s Mighty Adventure is based on Disney’s The Lion King as well as it’s direct-to-video sequel Simba’s Pride. The game consists of ten side-scrolling levels: The first six are set in The Lion King and the rest in Simba’s Pride, with some levels ending in boss fights. The game tracks along with the plot of both films and follows Simba as he grows up. Key events, such as the stampede from the first film, make up their own levels. Simba moves by running, jumping and climbing. Jumping can also be used to defeat the snakes, spiders, or monkeys that get in Simba’s way. He can also swipe at them with his claw or, as an adult, roar at them to make them flee.

Aiding Simba in his journey are collectibles that grant extra lives, refill or extend Simba’s health or fill a special amulet. Collecting all five parts of the amulet grants an extra life and opens up a mini-game that can be played main menu. The game also has a mulitplayer element. Using a Gameboy Colour link cable with another player opens up an extramode where each player has to hold onto a star for as long as possible by avoiding the opposing player’s attacks.

results.title: WipEout for Sega Saturn
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM and manual in Sega Saturn case
results.brief_description:
In the world of WipEout, anti-gravity racing is the world’s most popular sport. Tracks stretch out across the world and research is focused on finding even better and faster race craft. Racing for one of four corporations, the player competes to win the prestigious F3600 Anti-Gravity Racing League. Each corporation’s craft has its own strengths and weaknesses, which are further complicated by the choice of different pilots. Races aren’t simply affairs of speed and manoeuvring. The tracks are littered with weapons and powerups to hinder opponents or aid the player.

The game has three modes. Championship has the player attempting to place in the top three of each class, before proceeding to the next. If a player beats this mode in as the top of the Venom class, Rapier class, with tougher opponents, will be unlocked. Single Race pits the player against a full field of pilots in a single track. Time Trail is like single race, but without weapons.

results.title: Warlords II Deluxe for DOS
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM in CD jewel case
results.brief_description: An updated version of the original game, Warlords II Deluxe adds higher resolution graphics, new terrain types, new scenarios and improved AI. It also allows for the creation of custom tile, army, and city sets for the map. The game is bundled with an improved version of the Warlords II Scenario Builder.

results.title: Stargate for SNES
results.creator_credit: Acclaim Entertainment Ltd, Tantalus Media and Probe Software
results.brief_description: This action platform side-scroller set in the sci-fi universe of Stargate has the player rescuing the slaves of Abydos, defeating the evil villain Ra and getting his team back to Earth using the Stargate device. Most missions involve finding people or items in different locations, while fending off enemies with an upgradable machine gun and grenades. In addition, two missions has the player engaging in plane dogfights in one of Ra’s flying gliders. While the overall mission is to defeat Ra, seven bomb pieces and seven hieroglyphs must be collected beforehand or the player will lose the game even if they defeat Ra.

results.title: Manx TT SuperBike for Sega Saturn
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM and manual in plastic Sega Saturn games case
results.brief_description:
Set in the Isle of Man TT (Tourist Trophy), the world-famous and demanding motorcycle racing event held on the Isle of Man, this Saturn port of the arcade original has two courses to race on: The Laxey Coast course for novices and the more difficult TT Course. While the TT Course is based on the actual track, the Laxey Coast one is a developer creation, although it draws inspiration from the setting.

The Saturn version adds an Arcade Mode, which mimics the original arcade version and a Saturn Mode, which includes additional features such as practice races and a challenge course. Two-player multiplayer is supported via split screen and the game’s soundtrack can be listened to by placing the Saturn disc in a CD player.

results.title: Halloween Harry for PC
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM and CD envelope in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Halloween Harry is set in the 21st century, and features Harry, a ghost hunter, facing off against all sorts of evil across 13 levels. Essentially, it is a platform shooter with some puzzle-solving elements, set on a single screen.

The game instructions, which appear on the start screen, state: ‘It is the 21st century and from this futuristic new world comes an exciting new hero: HALLOWEEN HARRY! As Halloween Harry, a fearless ghost-hunter, you have been assigned to destroy an evil witch who has taken over a 13-room building. You do this by collecting the magic item in each room, then escape through a mystical door. There are 12 items to collect, ranging from a broom in room 1 to a cauldron in room 12. When all the items are collected, you must confront the witch in the 13th room. The witch is protected by a magical barrier, so you must collect a padlock and a key (in any order) so that her defence is broken down… Once exposed, you may zap the witch with your trusty garlic-blaster laser gun, (which has 13 shots). 3 additional shots may be obtained by grabbing the bonus garlic. To make your task difficult, the witch has summoned up various ghosts and ghouls, as well as the dreaded dropjaws and zombie hands to destroy you! Don’t forget there’s a time limit. It can be extended by the magic hourglass that appears when time is low.’

Source: Play It Again website:
http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/halloween-harry/

Last accessed: 11/05/2021

Original game developed by John Passfield. Published in 1985 by HoneySoft.

results.title: Asterix and the Magic Cauldron for Spectrum 48/128
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover and plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description:
Asterix and the Magic Cauldron is a single player adventure arcade game. Players control Asterix through various maps, collecting keys for locked doors and fighting Romans and boars in search of seven pieces of Getafix’s Magic Cauldron. Fights take place on a separate screen mode. Stamina bars for each combatant appear on the side of the window. Defeating the combatant adds it to the food tally. If Asterix loses the fight, the window closes and he loses a life. The same system is used when fighting the Roman soldiers and when Asterix picks up objects.

Obelix will only follow if Asterix has a supply of hams which can be obtained from fighting boars. Asterix starts with five lives and one dose of Magic Potion per game, which can be activated by double tapping the fire button.

Original game developed by Beam Software for ZX Spectrum 48K, published in 1986 by Melbourne House.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/asterix-and-the-magic-cauldron/

Last accessed: 1/05/2021

results.title: Hungry Horace for ZX Spectrum
results.creator_credit: Melbourne House, Psion Software and Beam Software
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette and cover in a plastic cassette case
results.brief_description:
Hungry Horace offered gameplay based of the popular arcade game Pac-Man. It was celebrated as the first arcade game for the Spectrum. It was one of the few Spectrum games that were also available in ROM format. It formed part of the Horace series, which included Horace Goes Skiing and Horace and the Spiders and the unpublished Horace to the Rescue.

Horace is a blue blob with arms and legs, who wanders around a maze, picking the flowers, collecting fruit and avoiding the park guards, who are out to capture him. He is able to momentarily scare the guards, making them vulnerable, by ringing a bell in the maze. If Horace is able to escape capture and leave the maze, he moves to the next, more challenging level.

Source: Play It Again website:
http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/hungry-horace-orginal-spectrum/

Last accessed: 17/05/2021

Original game developed by Beam Software and Psion Software. Published in 1982 by Melbourne House.
